questions.text: A 3-month-old baby comes with complaints of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The classical triad of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) strongly suggests congenital rubella syndrome.

  • Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS) occurs when rubella infection is acquired by the mother during early pregnancy, particularly within the first trimester.
  • The virus causes widespread fetal damage through viremia, which is most intense from 10 to 17 days after maternal infection.
  • The risk of congenital defects is highest in the first 12 weeks and significantly decreases after 20 weeks gestation.
  • The characteristic clinical features of CRS include:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) - the most common feature
    • Ocular defects - particularly cataracts (most common), glaucoma, and "salt and pepper" retinopathy
    • Cardiac anomalies - classically patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), followed by pulmonary artery stenosis and ventricular septal defect
    • Other features: microcephaly, intellectual disability, growth retardation, hepatitis, bone lesions, and increased risk of autoimmune conditions like diabetes and thyroid disorders.

  • Diagnosis is confirmed with Rubella-specific IgM, PCR for viral RNA, or viral culture.
  • Management is supportive, with no specific antiviral treatment.
  • Prevention is crucial and is achieved through vaccination (MMR/MMRV - live attenuated RA 27/3 strain), which is highly effective (95% after one dose, 99% after two doses).
  • Pregnant women exposed to rubella may be offered immunoglobulin, but it does not reliably prevent fetal infection.

Explanation of other options:

Congenital herpes simplex virus infection (Option A): Typically presents with skin vesicles, chorioretinitis, keratoconjunctivitis, and neurological complications like microcephaly or hydranencephaly. PDA and cataracts are not hallmark features.

Congenital toxoplasmosis (Option B): The classic triad includes chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications, not PDA or cataracts.

Congenital cytomegalovirus infection (Option C): Commonly presents with microcephaly, periventricular calcifications, chorioretinitis, and sensorineural hearing loss, but PDA and cataracts are not typical.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant presents with a cough and sore throat. The mother reports that the infant develops a paroxysm of cough followed by apnea. The total leukocyte count is >50,000 cells/μL. Which of the following drugs will you prescribe for this patient?
questions.solution:
Azithromycin is the first-line treatment for pertussis in all age groups, including infants under 1 month.

  • The clinical presentation of paroxysmal cough, apnea, and marked leukocytosis (>50,000 cells/μL) in a 3-week-old infant is highly suggestive of pertussis (whooping cough), a respiratory infection caused by Bordetella pertussis.
  • The illness progresses in three stages:
    • Catarrhal stage (1-2 weeks): mild URI symptoms
    • Paroxysmal stage (2-6 weeks): paroxysmal coughing with characteristic "whoop", post-tussive vomiting, and apnea in infants
    • Convalescent stage (1-4 weeks): gradual recovery
  • Pertussis can be dangerous in infants and may lead to pulmonary hypertension, cardiogenic shock, hemorrhage, seizures, and malnutrition.
  • Azithromycin is the drug of choice across all age groups due to its safety and efficacy.
  • It eradicates the bacteria from the nasopharynx and helps reduce the risk of transmission.
  • In infants <1 month old, erythromycin and clarithromycin are contraindicated because of the risk of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS).
  • Cotrimoxazole is also contraindicated in infants <2 months due to the risk of kernicterus.
  • Early treatment, preferably in the catarrhal stage, improves outcomes and reduces infectivity.
  • Infants with confirmed or suspected pertussis should also be isolated for at least 5 days after starting antibiotics.
  • Preventive measures include the DTaP vaccine for infants and Tdap vaccination during pregnancy (ideally between 27-36 weeks) to confer passive immunity to the newborn.

Explanation of other options:

Amoxicillin (Option B): Not effective against Bordetella pertussis; it targets gram-positive organisms, not the gram-negative coccobacilli responsible for pertussis.

Cotrimoxazole (Option C): Though it is an alternative in older children or adults allergic to macrolides, it is contraindicated in infants <2 months due to the risk of kernicterus.

Clarithromycin (Option D): Also effective against B. pertussis, but contraindicated in infants <1 month due to the risk of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS).

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK519008/

questions.text: A child is brought to the hospital with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor. The radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) presents with biphasic stridor and a characteristic "steeple sign" on X-ray due to subglottic narrowing.

  • Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup) is a viral infection of the glottic and subglottic regions of the airway.
  • Causative agents:
    • Most common: Parainfluenza viruses (types 1, 2, and 3) - ~75% of cases.
    • Other viruses:
      • Influenza A and B
      • Adenovirus
      • Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV)
      • Measles virus
  • Common in children aged 3 months to 5 years.
  • Peak incidence: 2nd year of life.
  • Initial Symptoms (last 1-3 days before airway obstruction)
    • Upper respiratory tract infection signs:
      • Rhinorrhea
      • Pharyngitis
      • Mild cough
      • Low-grade fever
    • Progressive symptoms:
      • Barking (seal-like) cough
      • Hoarseness
      • Inspiratory stridor
      • Fever (up to 39-40°C, or may be absent)
      • Child prefers sitting upright
      • Symptoms worse at night, recur over days, and resolve in a week
  • Physical examination findings:
    • Hoarse voice
    • Coryza
    • Mild-to-moderate pharyngeal inflammation
    • Slightly increased respiratory rate
    • Hypoxia/low SpO2 in severe airway obstruction
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical diagnosis based on history and exam
    • X-ray (PA neck): Steeple sign (subglottic narrowing)
  • Treatment:
    • Main goals: Airway management and hypoxia control
    • Mild Croup: Single dose of oral dexamethasone (0.6 mg/kg; 0.15 mg/kg may also be effective)
    • Moderate to Severe Croup
      • Nebulized racemic epinephrine + dexamethasone
      • Used in stridor at rest, respiratory distress, or hypoxia
      • May prevent need for intubation
    • Corticosteroids
      • Reduce laryngeal mucosal edema
      • Beneficial even in mild cases
    • Antibiotics: Not indicated (viral etiology)

Explanation of other options:

Acute epiglottitis (Option A): Presents acutely with high fever, drooling, dysphagia, and toxic appearance. The child often sits in a "tripod" position. Radiograph shows the thumb sign due to swollen epiglottis.

Foreign body aspiration (Option C): Sudden onset of cough, gagging, wheeze, or unilateral decreased breath sounds-not typically biphasic stridor. Chest X-ray may show air trapping or radiopaque objects.

Laryngomalacia (Option D): A congenital anomaly with chronic inspiratory stridor starting in early infancy, worsens with crying or feeding. Diagnosis is made by laryngoscopy, showing an omega-shaped epiglottis.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441873/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK431070/

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents to the pediatric OPD with complaints of persistent jaundice and pale (clay-colored) stools. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. Laboratory investigations show conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and liver biopsy reveals periductal proliferation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Biliary atresia presents in infancy with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, clay-colored stools, and shows periductal proliferation on liver biopsy.

  • Biliary atresia is a progressive fibro-obliterative disease of the extrahepatic biliary tree, often presenting in the first 2-6 weeks of life.
  • The key clinical features include:
    • Persistent jaundice
    • Acholic (clay-colored) stools
    • Dark urine
  • The histological hallmark is periductal fibrosis and bile duct proliferation, seen on liver biopsy.
  • Types:
    • Perinatal type (70%): No associated anomalies
    • BASM syndrome (15%): Includes Biliary atresia, Asplenia/polysplenia, Situs inversus, and other anomalies
    • Other syndromic associations (15%): Choledochal cysts, renal malformations
  • Investigations:
    • LFTs: Elevated conjugated bilirubin and cholestatic enzymes (ALP, GGT, 5'-nucleotidase)
    • Ultrasound: Absent gallbladder, "triangular cord sign"
    • HIDA scan: No tracer excretion despite phenobarbitone priming
    • Liver biopsy: Gold standard, shows periductal fibrosis and bile duct proliferation
    • Exploratory laparotomy with intraoperative cholangiogram: Confirmatory test
  • Management:
    • Kasai portoenterostomy (hepaticojejunostomy) within 8 weeks
    • Definitive treatment: Liver transplant

Explanation of other options:

Crigler-Najjar syndrome (Option A): Caused by glucuronyl transferase deficiency → results in unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. No periductal changes on biopsy.

Rotor syndrome (Option B): Caused by defects in hepatic organic anion transporters (SLCO1B1/1B3) → mild conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with normal liver histology.

Dubin-Johnson syndrome (Option C): Mutation in MRP2 gene → benign conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The liver appears black grossly due to pigment deposition, but no bile duct proliferation.

Reference:

https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/liverextrahepaticbiliaryatresia.html

questions.text: A child presents with growth failure. Biochemical analysis shows normal Ca2+, normal PTH, reduced phosphate, and increased ALP. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hypophosphatemic rickets presents with low phosphate, elevated ALP, and normal calcium and PTH, due to defective renal phosphate reabsorption.

  • Hypophosphatemic rickets (especially X-linked) is the most common hereditary cause of rickets.
  • It results from renal phosphate wasting despite normal vitamin D and calcium levels.
  • In these patients:
    • Serum phosphate is low due to proximal renal tubular phosphate loss.
    • Calcium remains normal because intestinal absorption is preserved.
    • PTH is normal or mildly elevated, unlike in nutritional rickets.
    • ALP is elevated due to increased osteoblastic activity during defective bone mineralization.
  • The child presents with growth failure, a key clinical feature.
  • Radiographic features of rickets such as metaphyseal fraying, cupping, and splaying are usually seen.

Explanation of other options:

Nutritional rickets (Option A): PTH is elevated, and calcium is often low or low-normal due to vitamin D deficiency. Also, 25(OH)D is decreased.

Type 1 VDDR (Option C): Caused by 1-alpha hydroxylase deficiency, leading to low 1,25(OH)2D, low calcium and phosphate, elevated PTH, and ALP. It does not show normal calcium and PTH.

Type 2 VDDR (Option D): Due to end-organ resistance to 1,25(OH)2D. Despite normal or elevated 1,25(OH)2D, calcium and phosphate are low, PTH is elevated, and ALP is raised.

choices.text: Nothing, as the child is already exposed

questions.text: Ajay, a 3-year-old child, is the younger brother of Anuj, who is currently undergoing treatment for diphtheria in the hospital. Ajay lives in the same household and received his diphtheria vaccination 16 months ago. What is the most appropriate course of action for the care of Ajay?
questions.solution:
Ajay is a household contact of a diphtheria case and should receive erythromycin prophylaxis, even though he is vaccinated and asymptomatic.

  • When a confirmed case of diphtheria is identified, close contacts (like household members) are at risk of asymptomatic carriage or developing the disease.
  • Recommended Management for Asymptomatic Close Contacts (like Ajay):
    • Antibiotic Prophylaxis:
      • Oral erythromycin 40-50 mg/kg/day (max 2 g/day) for 10 days
      • OR single dose of benzathine penicillin G
    • Vaccination Review:
      • Booster only if:
      • Less than 3 doses taken previously
      • No booster in the last 5 years
      • Ajay received his last diphtheria vaccine dose 16 months ago, so he does not need a booster now.
    • Monitoring:
      • Observe for symptoms for 7 days
      • Take cultures if symptoms develop

Explanation of other options:

One booster dose (Option A): Not needed now, as Ajay received a dose within the last 5 years. Boosters are only required if the last dose was ≥5 years ago.

Nothing, as the child is already exposed (Option B): Incorrect, because vaccination does not guarantee full protection, and exposed individuals can still become carriers or symptomatic.

Erythromycin + diphtheria toxoid (Option C): Not indicated in Ajay's case, as diphtheria toxoid is only added if: Immunization is incomplete or last booster was ≥5 years ago

choices.text: Galactosemia due to GAL-1-P uridyl transferase enzyme deficiency
Hereditary fructose intolerance due to aldolase B deficiency
Galactosemia due to galactokinase enzyme deficiency

questions.text: An infant presents with vomiting after feeding. A Benedict's test is performed and returns positive for a non-glucose reducing substance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A positive Benedict's test with vomiting after milk feeding in a neonate indicates classic galactosemia, due to GAL-1-P uridyl transferase deficiency.

  • Classic galactosemia is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder caused by deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT).
  • This leads to accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate and galactose in the blood and tissues after ingestion of lactose (milk sugar).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Onset after milk feeding (contains lactose → galactose)
    • Vomiting
    • Diarrhea
    • Jaundice
    • Hepatomegaly
    • Failure to thrive
    • Cataracts
    • Intellectual disability if untreated
    • Reducing substances (e.g., galactose) in urine → positive Benedict's test
  • Investigations:
    • Positive Benedict's test (detects reducing sugars, including galactose)
    • Enzyme assay for GALT activity
    • Confirmed by genetic testing
  • Management:
    • Eliminate galactose/lactose from diet (soy-based formula)
    • Early diagnosis prevents irreversible complications

Explanation of other options:

Hereditary fructose intolerance (Option B): Caused by aldolase B deficiency, presenting after fructose/sucrose ingestion (usually post-weaning), not soon after milk feeding. Benedict's test may be positive for fructose, but timing of symptoms doesn't match.

G6PD deficiency (Option C): Leads to hemolysis, especially after oxidative stress (e.g., infection, fava beans, certain drugs). No vomiting after feeding or positive Benedict's test expected.

Galactokinase deficiency (Option D): A milder form of galactosemia presenting primarily with cataracts, without systemic symptoms like vomiting or hepatomegaly. Benedict's test may still be positive, but not as severe as GALT deficiency.

questions.text: A 12-year-old female patient with more than 104 colonies of novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus in Urine Culture. What is the expected course of action?
questions.solution:
The presence of novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus (likely Staphylococcus saprophyticus) in significant numbers (>10ˆ4 colonies) suggests a urinary tract infection.

Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs)

Etiology and Prevalence:

  • Primary Cause: Colonic bacteria ascending the urinary tract.
  • Common Pathogen: Escherichia coli (54-67% of cases).
  • Other Pathogens: Klebsiella spp., Proteus spp., Enterococcus, Pseudomonas, Staphylococcus saprophyticus.

Clinical Features and Classification:

  • Pyelonephritis (Kidney Infection): Upper renal collecting system involved
    • Symptoms: Abdominal/back/flank pain, fever, malaise, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea.
    • Newborns: Non-specific symptoms like poor feeding, irritability, jaundice, weight loss.
  • Cystitis (Bladder Infection): Only bladder involved
    • Symptoms: Dysuria, urgency, frequency, suprapubic pain, incontinence, malodorous urine.
    • Typically does not cause high fever or renal injury.

Risk Factors for Recurrent UTI:

  • Vesicoureteral Reflux (VUR)
  • Bladder-Bowel Dysfunction (BBD)
  • Obstructive Uropathy
  • Urinary Tract Abnormalities: Anatomical issues like labial adhesion.
  • Neuropathic Bladder
  • Catheterisation: Procedures introducing bacteria.
  • Sexual Activity: Increases UTI risk in females.

Diagnosis:

  • Urine Culture: Gold standard for UTI diagnosis; identifies and quantifies bacteria.

Interpretation:

A colony count of >50,000 colony-forming units/mL of a single pathogen, along with pyuria or bacteriuria in a symptomatic child, is generally considered diagnostic of a UTI.

  • Urinalysis: Leukocyte Esterase and Nitrites positive.

Imaging Studies:

Treatment:

  • Antibiotic Therapy: Mainstay of UTI treatment.

Explanation for other options:

Take three urine samples (Option B) Multiple urine samples are needed for bloodstream infections (bacteremia), not for UTIs.

No treatment is needed (Option C) A colony count ≥104 CFU/mL in a symptomatic patient requires treatment.

Contaminated sample (Option D) S. saprophyticus is a known UTI pathogen, not a contaminant like other CoNS (e.g., S. epidermidis).

questions.text: Which neonatal anomaly is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
Exstrophy bladder is a congenital anomaly where the bladder mucosa is exposed outside the abdominal wall due to failure of mesodermal migration.

  • Bladder exstrophy results from a failure of mesoderm to migrate and form the lower abdominal wall, leading to a defect through which the posterior bladder wall protrudes and is visible externally.
  • It typically presents in neonates with the bladder mucosa exposed, downwardly displaced umbilicus, widely separated pubic symphysis, and epispadias.
  • In males, dorsal chordee and shortened penis are seen.
  • In females, there is bifid clitoris and wide labial separation.
  • If left untreated, patients suffer from complete urinary incontinence and are at increased risk for bladder adenocarcinoma.
  • This condition is easily distinguishable from other anterior abdominal wall defects due to visible bladder mucosa, absence of a herniated bowel sac, and association with genital anomalies.

Explanation of other options:

Omphalocele (Option A): Presents as herniation of abdominal contents into the base of the umbilical cord, covered by a translucent sac. The umbilical cord inserts into the sac-not seen in exstrophy.

Gastroschisis (Option B): Abdominal wall defect lateral to the umbilicus, with free-floating bowel loops that lack a covering sac-distinct from bladder mucosa exposure.

Patent vitello intestinal duct (Option C): Persistent communication between the intestine and umbilicus, may present as a fistula, sinus, or cyst near the umbilicus-does not show an exposed bladder.

questions.text: A 6-week-old infant is brought to the emergency department with repeated episodes of forceful, non-bilious vomiting. Based on the accompanying radiograph, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph reveals a thickened and elongated pyloric region, in conjunction with the clinical symptoms, which are indicative of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS).

CHPS is caused by muscular hypertrophy of the pylorus, resulting in obstruction at the gastric outlet. It typically affects male infants between 2 to 6 weeks of age.

Clinical Features:

  • Symptoms: Repeated projectile vomiting that is non-bilious, usually following feeds, beginning at around 2-6 weeks of life.
  • Examination Findings: Observable gastric peristalsis and a firm, mobile, "olive-shaped" mass palpable in the epigastric area.

Diagnostic Approach:

  • Ultrasonography (preferred investigation):
    • Pyloric muscle thickness > 3 mm
    • Pyloric canal length > 14 mm
    • Elongated, thickened pyloric appearance (typically 10-14 mm)
  • Contrast-enhanced Upper GI Series (less commonly used):
    Reveals characteristic signs and delayed gastric emptying without duodenal dilation.

Explanation for other options:

Annular pancreas (Option A): Can also cause non-bilious vomiting and is associated with Down syndrome and duodenal atresia, but the image and clinical context favour CHPS.

Duodenal atresia (Option C): Characterised by bilious vomiting and the classic "double bubble" appearance on X-ray.

Meckel's diverticulum (Option D): Typically presents with painless gastrointestinal bleeding, not vomiting.

questions.text: A newborn girl presents with ambiguous genitalia, clitoromegaly, and labial fusion. She is found to have normal internal female organs. Laboratory tests reveal hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone. What is the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is female pseudohermaphroditism due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency, the most common form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Excess prenatal androgens virilize 46,XX fetuses, while cortisol and aldosterone deficiency lead to electrolyte abnormalities.

Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH):

  • Predominantly due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  • Hormonal Variants:
    • Salt-wasting form: Both cortisol and aldosterone are deficient.
    • Simple virilizing form: Aldosterone is preserved; excess androgens are produced.
    • Nonclassic form: Mild androgen excess; symptoms may be absent or minimal.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Aldosterone and Cortisol Deficiency (in salt-wasting form):
      • Seen in about 70% of CAH patients.
      • Symptoms include weight loss, vomiting, dehydration, low blood pressure, low blood sugar, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia.
    • Effects of Androgen Excess in Utero:
      • In 46,XX individuals (genetic females), elevated prenatal androgens cause genital virilization, leading to:
        • Enlarged clitoris (clitoromegaly)
        • Fusion of labia
        • Formation of a common urogenital sinus
      • However, internal reproductive organs (uterus and ovaries) are normal since there is no antimüllerian hormone being produced.
      • In 46,XY infants (genetic males), the genitalia appear typical at birth, often delaying diagnosis until symptoms of adrenal insufficiency appear.
    • Postnatal Androgen Excess:
      • Males: May present with enlarged phallus, small prepubertal testes, or develop testicular adrenal rest tumors.
      • Females: Can develop progressive clitoromegaly, primary amenorrhea, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics without treatment.
  • Laboratory Findings:
    • Salt-wasting form: Electrolyte imbalances including low sodium, high potassium, metabolic acidosis, and hypoglycemia.
    • Hormonal profile shows increased 17-hydroxyprogesterone, androstenedione, and testosterone (especially in females).
    • ACTH stimulation test: A significant rise in 17-hydroxyprogesterone confirms CAH diagnosis.
  • Management:
    • Medical Therapy:
      • Glucocorticoids: Replace cortisol and suppress excess androgen production.
      • Mineralocorticoids: Required in salt-wasting cases to correct aldosterone deficiency.
    • Surgical Interventions:
      • Clitoral reduction surgery may be considered in cases of severe clitoromegaly.
      • Vaginoplasty and correction of urogenital sinus anomalies may also be needed.

Explanation of other options:

Male pseudohermaphroditism (Option A): Typically results from 17α-hydroxylase deficiency, not 21-hydroxylase deficiency. These individuals have 46,XY karyotype but incomplete virilization.

True hermaphroditism (Option C): Characterized by the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue, which is not a feature of CAH.

46, XY intersex(Option D): Includes conditions with ambiguous genitalia in 46, XY individuals due to enzyme defects or androgen insensitivity, but differs from 21-hydroxylase deficiency CAH, which usually affects 46, XX individuals.

questions.text: A newborn presents with persistent unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia lasting beyond 3 weeks of age. Investigations show normal liver enzymes, normal PT/INR, and normal albumin levels. No signs of hemolysis are noted on peripheral smear. Following phenobarbital therapy, a notable decline in bilirubin levels is observed within a week. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: This clinical scenario is indicative of a nonhemolytic unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in a neonate with preserved liver function. The significant improvement after phenobarbital administration is characteristic of Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 2, making it the most probable diagnosis.

questions.text: A newborn is evaluated 5 minutes after birth. The baby is cyanotic, has irregular and gasping respiration, a heart rate of 60 beats per minute, minimal response to stimulation, and exhibits some flexion of limbs. What is the most accurate Apgar score?
questions.solution:
Apgar score is calculated as follows:

  • Appearance (skin color): Baby is completely cyanosed - Score 0.
  • Pulse (heart rate): Heart rate is 60 beats per minute (below 100) - Score 1.
  • Grimace (reflex irritability): Minimal response to stimulation - Score 1.
  • Activity (muscle tone): Baby shows some flexion of extremities - Score 1.
  • Respiratory effort: Breathing is irregular and gasping - Score 1.

Adding all the components: 0 (appearance) + 1 (pulse) + 1 (grimace) + 1 (activity) + 1 (respiration) = Apgar score of 4.

Apgar Scoring System:

  • Assessed at 1 and 5 minutes post-delivery to evaluate the newborn's cardiopulmonary status and adaptation to the postnatal environment.
  • If the 5-minute score is less than 7, it is repeated every 5 minutes up to 20 minutes.
  • A score between 0-3 at 5 minutes is associated with a higher risk of mortality.
  • The Apgar score assesses a newborn's condition at 1 and 5 minutes post-delivery.
    • Scores of 0-3 at 5 minutes indicate a need for urgent resuscitation and are associated with higher risk of morbidity.
    • Scores of 4-6 suggest the need for supportive measures.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with seizures. He had a febrile illness with a rash at the age of 1 year, which resolved spontaneously. Which of the following investigations would be most useful in establishing the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of seizures in a school-aged child, coupled with a history of a self-limited febrile exanthem in infancy, raises suspicion for Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE), a progressive and fatal delayed complication of a prior measles infection. Detection of elevated measles-specific IgG antibodies in cerebrospinal fluid is a cornerstone of diagnosis, reflecting prior infection and ongoing CNS involvement.

Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis

  • Definition: A fatal, slowly progressive neurological disorder caused by persistent measles virus in the brain, manifesting years after the initial infection. Also called Dawson disease or slow-virus encephalitis.
  • Onset: Usually emerges 7-13 years following measles infection.
  • Symptoms: Gradual development of behavioral issues, cognitive decline, myoclonic jerks, and progressive neurological impairment.
  • EEG Findings: Periodic high-voltage discharges and burst-suppression complexes.
  • Neuroimaging: MRI may show generalized brain atrophy and white matter changes but is not diagnostic.
  • Diagnosis: Based on history, clinical course, characteristic EEG, and elevated measles-specific IgG levels in the CSF.

Explanation of other options:

MRI mesial temporal lobe sclerosis (Option B): This MRI finding is associated with temporal lobe epilepsy and involves structural changes in the mesial temporal region (especially the hippocampus). It does not confirm SSPE.

lgM measles in CSF (Option C): IgM antibodies indicate a recent measles infection. Since SSPE manifests years after the initial episode, IgM is typically absent and not useful for diagnosis.

Anti-C1q antibodies in the CSF (Option D): These are not associated with measles or subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE). They are primarily linked to autoimmune disorders, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), especially in cases with lupus nephritis.

choices.text: Severe malnutrition - refer to nutrition rehabilitation centre
Moderate malnutrition - educate the mother on feeding practices

questions.text: A 16-month-old boy weighs 8 kg. Based on the WHO weight-for-age growth chart provided below, what would be the most appropriate course of action?
questions.solution:
• At 16 months of age, a weight of 8 kg places this child between -2 SD and -3 SD from the mean on the WHO weight-for-age reference chart. This range classifies him as moderately underweight, indicating moderate malnutrition.
  • While his nutritional status is compromised, it does not yet meet the criteria for severe malnutrition, and therefore, immediate referral to a nutrition rehabilitation center is not warranted.
  • Instead, the focus should be on educating the mother or caregiver on proper feeding practices and providing guidance on improving the child's nutritional intake.
  • This may involve promoting a balanced diet, ensuring adequate calorie and nutrient intake, and addressing any feeding difficulties or challenges.

WHO Growth Charts:

  • Developed through the WHO Multicentre Growth Reference Study (MGRS) conducted in multiple countries (India, Brazil, Ghana, Norway, Oman, and the USA).
  • Charts are used to assess growth parameters in children under 5.
  • The chart uses percentile or Z-score curves to monitor trends in weight, height/length, and head circumference.
  • Z-score Classification for Weight-for-Age:
    • Normal range: Between -2 SD and +2 SD
    • Mild underweight: Between -2 SD and -1 SD
    • Moderate underweight: Between -3 SD and -2 SD
    • Severe underweight: Below -3 SD

questions.text: A full-term 8-day-old neonate is found to have a thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level exceeding 100 mIU/L on newborn screening. Which of the following would be the most appropriate next diagnostic step?
questions.solution:
In a newborn with markedly elevated TSH, congenital hypothyroidism is suspected. The next best investigation is a thyroid scan using technetium-99m pertechnetate to assess the presence, location, and functional status of thyroid tissue. This helps differentiate between thyroid dysgenesis (agenesis, ectopia), and dyshormonogenesis.

Congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Is the most common preventable cause of mental retardation, which results from a deficient production of thyroid hormone.
  • More common among girls
  • The most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism is thyroid dysgenesis.
  • Etiology of congenital hypothyroidism:
  1. Primary hypothyroidism:
    • Thyroid dysgenesis
    • Thyroid dyshormonogenesis
    • Iodine deficiency
    • Transport defects from MCT8 gene mutations
    • Transplacental passage of maternal thyrotropin receptor-blocking antibodies (TRBAb)
    • Antithyroid drugs taken by the mother
  2. Central (hypopituitary) hypothyroidism:
    • Prolonged neonatal jaundice
    • Treatment-resistant constipation
    • Wide anterior/posterior fontanelles
    • Macroglossia
    • Developmental delays
    • Poor growth
    • Delayed teeth eruption
    • Hypotonia, hypothermia
    • Macrocytic anemia that does not respond to treatment.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Primary hypothyroidism is characterized by very low T4 and TSH levels exceeding 100 mIU/L.
    • Central hypothyroidism presents with low T3, T4, and TSH.
    • Radionuclide scan (Technetium-99m or Iodine-123) or thyroid ultrasound is essential to determine the gland's location, size, and structure, helping identify dysgenesis, dyshormonogenesis, or transient forms.
  • Management:
    • Oral levothyroxine is the treatment of choice.
    • Dose adjustments are age-dependent:
      • Neonates: 10-15 mcg/kg/day
      • Children: 2-4 mcg/kg/day

Explanation of other options:

Urine iodine excretion (Option A): Best used in public health settings to assess population-level iodine nutrition, not for individual diagnosis.

Serum thyroid receptor antibody (Option B): Primarily relevant if maternal autoimmune thyroid disease is suspected; useful in cases of transient neonatal hypothyroidism.

Perchlorate secretion test (Option D): Identifies defects in iodine organification (e.g., TPO deficiency), but is not a first-line investigation for congenital hypothyroidism.

Reference:

https://www.msdmanuals.com/professional/pediatrics/endocrine-disorders-in-children/hypothyroidism-in-infants-and-children#

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant presents with sudden flexion jerks of the limbs and has shown a loss of previously attained developmental milestones. On EEG, a chaotic pattern of high-voltage slow waves with multifocal waves and spikes is observed. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
The child's presentation of flexor spasms, developmental regression, and the presence of hypsarrhythmia on EEG is indicative of West syndrome, also known as infantile spasms. The preferred initial therapy is ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic hormone).

West Syndrome:

  • Typical Age of Onset: Usually occurs between 2 to 12 months of age.
  • Genetics:ARX gene mutations are implicated, especially in male infants, linked to ambiguous genitalia and cortical migration abnormalities.
  • Clinical Signs:
    • Epileptic Spasms: Sudden, brief muscle contractions that happen in clusters, often during transitions from sleep.
    • Developmental Regression: Loss of previously acquired skills.
    • Hypsarrhythmia on EEG: Characterized by high-amplitude, disorganized background activity with multifocal spikes and waves.
  • Treatment Approach:
    • ACTH Therapy: First-line treatment.
      • Dosage: 150 units/m²/day (administered as 75 units/mm² twice daily) for 2 weeks, followed by a taper.
      • Monitoring: EEG at weeks 1, 2, and 4 to monitor effectiveness.
    • Alternative & Adjunct Treatments:
      • Oral Prednisolone: A more economical but less potent alternative to ACTH.
      • Vigabatrin: Especially useful if West syndrome is associated with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC); risk of retinal toxicity is a concern.
      • Ketogenic Diet: Considered if initial therapies fail.

Explanation of other options:

Phenytoin (Option A): Mainly used for focal seizures and status epilepticus; it does not address infantile spasms or EEG abnormalities like hypsarrhythmia.

Levetiracetam (Option C): Has no proven efficacy for infantile spasms.

Phenobarbitone (Option D): Although it's a common choice in neonatal seizures, it is less effective for infantile spasms compared to ACTH.

choices.text: Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour
Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

questions.text: A 10-year-old child weighing 30 kg is brought in with a 2-day history of diarrhea. On assessment, the child appears severely dehydrated. Laboratory findings include a random blood sugar of 550 mg/dL, blood pH of 7.01, serum sodium of 158 mEq/L, and urine positive for glucose (3+). What is the initial management as per ISPAD guidelines?
questions.solution:
The clinical and laboratory profile, including profound dehydration, hyperglycemia (RBS 550 mg/dL), acidemia (pH 7.01), and significant glycosuria, suggests a diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). Per ISPAD recommendations, the child should first receive resuscitative care with normal saline at 20 mL/kg, while insulin infusion 0.1 IU/kg/hr should be initiated only after one hour of fluid therapy.

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA):

  • DKA is a common acute complication observed in children and adolescents with both type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus.
  • Clinical Signs:
    • Dehydration
    • Tachycardia and tachypnea.
    • Kussmaul breathing: Characterized by deep, labored respiration with a fruity or acetone-like smell on the breath.
    • Gastrointestinal issues: Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
    • Neurological involvement: Drowsiness, disorientation, or gradual decline in consciousness.
  • Biochemical Parameters for Diagnosis:
    • Hyperglycemia: Blood glucose >11 mmol/L or ≥200 mg/dL.
    • Acidosis: Venous: pH <7.3 and/or bicarbonate <15 mmol/L.
    • Ketone Accumulation:
      • In blood (Ketonemia): β-hydroxybutyrate concentration ≥3 mmol/L.
      • In urine (Ketonuria): Detected as moderate to large ketone levels.
  • Management:

Reference:

  1. Pediatric Diabetic Ketoacidosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf
  2. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4413392/

choices.text: Increase in length of 25 centimetres in the first year
Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year
Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age
Weight under the 75th percentile and height under the 25th percentile

questions.text: Which of the following most reliably indicates appropriate physical growth in an infant born with a weight of 2.8 kg?
questions.solution:
A 25 cm increase in length during the first year is considered the most reliable marker of appropriate growth in infancy.

Normal Growth Milestones:

  • At birth: Length is approximately 50 cm.
  • At 1 year: Expected to reach 75 cm.
  • At 2 years: Increases by 10-15 cm to reach about 85-90 cm.
  • From age 2 to 12: Linear growth continues at around 6 cm/year.

Height Landmarks:

  • Doubles by around 4 years.
  • Triples by 12 years.
  • At 2 years, a child achieves about 50% of adult height (80-85 cm).

Growth Chart Formulas - Weech's Rule:

  • <1 year: (Age in months + 9) ÷ 2
  • 1-6 years: (2 × age in years) + 8
  • 7-12 years: (7 × age in years - 5) ÷ 2

Explanation of other options:

Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year (Option B): Weight gain of 300g/month is below the typical rate, especially in early months where 20-40g/day is expected, and gain reaches ~400g/month after 4 months.

Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age (Option C): The anterior fontanelle typically closes between 9-18 months, not by 6 months, and varies significantly, hence not a consistent growth marker.

Weight under the 75th percentile and height under the 25th percentile (Option D): While percentiles help compare with population norms, being below the 75th percentile for weight and 25th percentile for height does not inherently imply healthy or adequate growth.

Reference:

  1. https://www.pedgen.org.in/growth.php
  2. https://journals.lww.com/njcp/fulltext/2020/23090/comparison_of_age_based_weight_estimation_with.8.aspx

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a history of sudden-onset rapid heart rate. He is alert, playful, and has stable vital signs. The ECG is shown below. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
For a child with PSVT who remains hemodynamically stable, adenosine at a dose of 0.1 mg/kg administered intravenously is the preferred initial therapy. It exerts its effect by causing a transient block in AV nodal conduction, often restoring normal sinus rhythm effectively.

Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT):

  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Abrupt onset of a rapid and regular heartbeat
    • Feelings of dizziness or unsteadiness
    • Shortness of breath
    • Chest pressure or discomfort
    • Increased anxiety
    • Tiredness
    • In advanced cases: fainting, low blood pressure, or heart failure symptoms
  • Electrocardiographic Features:
    • Narrow QRS complexes (duration <120 ms) with regular rhythm
    • Shortened R-R intervals
    • Heart rate ranging from 150-250 bpm
    • P waves might be indistinct or merged with T waves
  • Subtypes:
    • AV Nodal Reentrant Tachycardia (AVNRT): Retrograde P waves may present as pseudo R' in V1 or pseudo S waves in inferior leads
    • AV Reentrant Tachycardia (AVRT): Retrograde P waves may follow the QRS complex

      Fig: Typical AVNRT terminated by carotid sinus massage

  • Management:
    • Acute Intervention:
      • First Step: Try vagal maneuvers (e.g., Valsalva, carotid sinus massage)
      • If Ineffective: Administer IV adenosine as first-line drug
        • A pediatric dose of 0.1 mg/kg of adenosine IV is appropriate
        • If ineffective, the dose may be escalated (up to 0.2 mg/kg) (Option B)
        • Standard dosing: 6-12 mg rapid IV push (in adults)
    • Alternatives: Verapamil, diltiazem, beta-blockers
    • For Unstable Patients: Use synchronized cardioversion
  • Long-Term Strategies:
    • Catheter ablation is often curative in recurrent AVNRT or AVRT
    • Medication options: Beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers to prevent recurrence
    • Selected Cases: Class IC or III antiarrhythmics
  • Lifestyle Tips: Avoid common triggers (caffeine, alcohol, emotional stress), ensure regular exercise and proper sleep

Explanation of other options:

Cardioversion (Option A): Reserved for unstable PSVT or drug-refractory cases, not suitable when vitals are stable.

IV Adrenaline (Option D): Not part of PSVT treatment; indicated in cardiac arrest or anaphylaxis.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic with petechiae and purpura. On examination, there is hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory tests show hemoglobin of 7 g/dL and a total leukocyte count of 50,000/mm³. What is the most appropriate initial pharmacologic management?
questions.solution:
The combination of clinical signs, such as hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, leukocytosis, and bleeding symptoms in a child, is highly indicative of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). The recommended initial pharmacologic approach for such a diagnosis commonly includes Vincristine and Prednisolone.


Explanation of other options:

Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) (Option B): Though effective in treating immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), it does not serve as a frontline therapy for ALL.

L-Asparaginase + Prednisolone (Option C): While part of the broader ALL regimen, this pair is generally used in combination with other drugs like Vincristine and is not typically used in isolation as initial therapy.

Daunorubicin + Prednisolone (Option D): This pairing is more frequently seen in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and is not the preferred initial treatment for ALL.

questions.text: A term neonate born after prolonged labor develops lethargy and hypotonia within 6 hours of birth. The baby has a weak Moro reflex, poor suck, and experiences seizures on day 1. On examination, the pupils are constricted (miosis), and EEG shows low-voltage theta and delta waves. Based on these findings, the most appropriate Sarnat stage of Hypoxic Ischemic Encephalopathy is:
questions.solution:
• The clinical findings - lethargy, hypotonia, weak reflexes, miosis, seizures, and abnormal EEG - are hallmark features of Stage 2 HIE in the Sarnat staging system.
  • This stage is moderate HIE, and timely intervention (like therapeutic hypothermia in appropriate settings) may improve neurological outcomes.

Sarnat and Sarnat Staging:

This classification is based on:

  • Mental status
  • Muscle tone
  • Autonomic function (e.g., pupils, heart rate)
  • Seizure activity
  • EEG pattern

Knowing these stages is crucial because:

  • Stage 1 usually resolves without a neurological deficit.
  • Stage 2 has ~20-35% chance of adverse outcomes.
  • Stage 3 has poor prognosis, with high mortality and neurodevelopmental impairment.

Hypoxic Ischemic Encephalopathy (HIE):

It is a type of brain dysfunction that occurs when the brain does not receive enough oxygen (hypoxia) and/or blood flow (ischemia) for a period of time, particularly around the time of birth.

Causes of Perinatal Asphyxia Leading to HIE:

  • Uteroplacental insufficiency
  • Prolonged or obstructed labour
  • Umbilical cord compression/prolapse
  • Placental abruption
  • Maternal hypotension or cardiac arrest
  • Severe neonatal anaemia (e.g., fetomaternal hemorrhage)

Pathophysiology of HIE:

  1. Initial insult: Lack of oxygen/blood → energy failure → cellular dysfunction.
  2. Reperfusion phase: Restoration of blood leads to free radical damage, calcium influx, and apoptosis.
  3. Secondary energy failure: Occurs after 6-48 hours; critical window for therapeutic intervention (e.g., hypothermia).

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical signs (altered consciousness, seizures, abnormal tone)
  • APGAR score <3 for more than 5 minutes
  • Need for resuscitation >10 minutes
  • Multisystem organ involvement
  • MRI/EEG findings may help assess severity and prognosis

Treatment:

  • Therapeutic hypothermia:
    • Initiate within 6 hours of birth
    • Continue for 72 hours
    • Reduces cerebral metabolic demand and apoptosis
    • Improves neurodevelopmental outcomes if given early in moderate HIE
  • Supportive care:
    • Manage seizures (Phenobarbitone is first-line)
    • Maintain ventilation, perfusion, glucose, and electrolytes
    • Monitor organ function (renal, hepatic, cardiac)

Stage 1 (Mild) (Option A): Stage I HIE usually presents with hyperalertness, normal tone, brisk reflexes, and no seizures, with a normal EEG. The presence of lethargy, hypotonia, and seizures here clearly rules this out.

Stage 3 (Severe) (Option C): Stage III involves coma or stupor, absent reflexes, flaccid tone, and an isoelectric (flat) EEG. This neonate is lethargic but not comatose, and has low-voltage EEG, not a flat one.

No HIE - Normal findings (Option D): The neonate has multiple signs of neurological dysfunction (seizures, tone abnormalities, EEG changes), strongly indicating hypoxic encephalopathy, not a normal perinatal transition.

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10874515

choices.text: Suction the nose first, followed by the mouth
Routine suctioning of mouth and nose is recommended in all deliveries
Suction the mouth first, then the nose if needed

questions.text: A term neonate is delivered through meconium-stained amniotic fluid. Immediately after birth, the baby is vigorous with a good tone and strong cry. The healthcare team prepares for routine neonatal resuscitation under a radiant warmer. Which of the following is the most appropriate step regarding airway management in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Neonatal resuscitation is a critical skill aimed at stabilizing newborns with compromised respiration and circulation after birth. As per the 2020 AHA/AAP Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP) guidelines, suctioning should only be performed if there is an obstruction or excessive secretions.

In neonates born through meconium-stained liquor, the vigorous baby (crying, HR > 100 bpm, good tone)does NOT need deep (tracheal) suctioning. Instead, if necessary, gentle suctioning should be performed with a bulb syringe or suction catheter, and the correct order is:

Mouth first → then nose

("M before N" - to prevent aspiration if the baby gasps)

Routine suctioning of all neonates is no longer recommended, as it may delay initiation of ventilation and even cause bradycardia due to vagal stimulation.

Neonatal Resuscitation:

  • Definition: Life-saving steps to support breathing/circulation after birth.
  • Burden: Birth asphyxia causes ~19% of neonatal deaths in India.
  • Need:
    • 85% of newborns breathe spontaneously.
    • 10% need basic support (drying/stimulation).
    • 5% need PPV.
  • Consequences: Impaired lung fluid clearance, hypoxemia, poor pulmonary flow, multiorgan dysfunction.

Resuscitation Preparation:

  • Team readiness: Assign roles, check equipment.
  • Equipment includes:
    • Suction: Catheters, meconium aspirator
    • Airway: Bag/mask, oxygen
    • Intubation: ET tubes, laryngoscope
    • Drugs: Epinephrine, saline
    • Others: Warm linen, stethoscope, feeding tube
  • PPV Correction (MR SOPA): Mask, Reposition, Suction, Open mouth, Pressure ↑, Alt. airway
  • Drugs: Epinephrine (0.2 mL/kg IV), saline 10 mL/kg if hypovolemic

Post-Resuscitation Care:

  • Monitor vitals, temperature, glucose
  • Begin breastfeeding if stable
  • Avoid routine suctioning; it may cause bradycardia or delay ventilation.
  • Always prioritize PPV if breathing is inadequate.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8606598

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant is brought to the clinic for a routine check-up. The mother reports that the child is able to sit without support, creep on all fours, and pull himself up to stand using furniture, but has not yet started to walk independently. Which of the following developmental abilities is most appropriate for his age?
questions.solution:
Developmental Milestone: Gross Motor Skill (10 Months)

  • At 10 months, the typical gross motor milestones include:
    • Sitting without support
    • Creeping (abdomen off ground)
    • Pulling to stand using furniture
    • Walking independently is expected only between 13-15 months, so its absence at 10 months is normal.

Core Concepts of Development:

  • Development begins in utero and continues to maturity.
  • Milestone sequence is constant; timing may vary.
  • Development follows three main principles:
    • Cephalocaudal: Head-to-toe (e.g., head control → trunk → legs).
    • Proximal to distal: Midline to periphery (e.g., arm → hand → fingers).
    • Neurological maturation: Myelination and CNS maturity are prerequisites for skill acquisition.
  • >80% brain development occurs in the first 3 years.

Domains of Development & Key Milestones:





Factors Influencing Development

A. Biological & Genetic

  • Genetics: Inherited disorders (e.g., Down, Turner syndrome).
  • Maternal health: Poor nutrition, infections (rubella), drug exposure.
  • Perinatal: Prematurity, SGA, birth asphyxia, jaundice.
  • Nutrition: Deficiencies (e.g., iodine, vitamin A/D).
  • Infections: Chronic (e.g., HIV, malaria, meningitis).
  • Toxins: Lead, mercury, arsenic exposure.
  • Brain insults: TBI, encephalitis.
  • Sensory deficits: Vision/hearing impairments.

B. Psychosocial & Environmental

  • Parenting quality: Responsiveness, warmth.
  • Socioeconomic status: Poverty affects nutrition, stimulation.
  • Emotional environment: Insecurity, stress impacts growth hormones.
  • Abuse: Psychological trauma.
  • Institutional care: Risk for attachment, emotional issues.

Assessment & Delays:

  • Developmental surveillance: Regular monitoring during health visits.
  • Developmental screening: Brief, standardised tools to detect delays.

Developmental Quotient (DQ):

  • DQ = (Developmental Age / Chronological Age) × 100
  • DQ < 70 → warrants full evaluation



Early Intervention:

  • Goal: Maximise potential in children with delays.
  • Services: Special education, speech therapy, occupational/physical therapy.
  • Importance: Early detection and treatment lead to better outcomes.

choices.text: Observation as this will likely resolve as the baby grows

questions.text: A healthy term baby girl is born via elective cesarean delivery due to breech presentation. On physical exam, when abducting and rotating the infant's legs you hear a "clunk" on the left hip. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality for suspected developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) in infants under 4-6 months-especially with a positive Ortolani clunk and high-risk factors like breech presentation-because the femoral head is still cartilaginous and invisible on X-ray

  • Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) is a condition at birth in which the femoral head and the acetabulum are misaligned or grow abnormally.
  • If not detected early, the hip joint will grow abnormally resulting in degenerative joint disease, impaired walking, chronic pain, or permanent disability.
  • Currently, the guidelines for screening are serial physical examinations up to one year of age using the Barlow and Ortolani maneuvers and ultrasonography.
  • The Barlow exam is done by adducting a flexed hip, and the Ortolani is performed by abducting a flexed hip. Both exams are done to identify a dislocatable hip.
  • A positive Ortolani or Barlow indicates the need for further investigation with ultrasonography.
  • Treatment of DDH varies depending on the age of discovery and severity.
  • The Pavlik method is a common nonsurgical method that positions the baby's hip in a way that the joints align and the baby can grow normally.
  • Surgical interventions are reserved for more severe cases, late diagnosis, or failed nonsurgical treatment.

X-ray of both hips (Option D) - Not useful in newborns since the femoral head is cartilaginous until ~4-months, making X-rays insensitive early on .

MRI of both hips (Option A) - Unnecessary and impractical as first-line imaging; ultrasound is non-invasive, readily available, and sufficient unless complex pathology is suspected.

Observation (Option B) - Risky; a true Ortolani clunk indicates instability that needs imaging and possible early treatment-watchful waiting isn't recommended in this scenario

questions.text: A teenage girl presents with a history of unintentionally dropping objects from her hands, particularly in the early mornings and during periods of stress such as examinations. There is no associated loss of consciousness. A family member has been diagnosed with epilepsy. EEG reveals epileptic discharges. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presentation of sudden hand jerks in the morning and during stressful events (e.g., exams) in an adolescent, along with a family history of epilepsy and EEG showing epileptic activity, is characteristic of Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME).

Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME):

  • Also known as Janz syndrome, it is a type of generalized epilepsy.
  • Onset typically occurs during early adolescence (ages 12-18).
  • Characterized by bilateral myoclonic jerks, especially soon after waking up.
    • Patients may drop objects in the morning due to sudden myoclonic jerks.
  • Generalized tonic-clonic seizures may also be seen, often occurring on awakening.
  • EEG shows generalized polyspike-wave discharges, typically 4-6 Hz.
  • Family history of epilepsy and epileptic EEG patterns support the diagnosis.
  • Triggers include lack of sleep, alcohol intake, and photic stimulation.
  • Treatment Approach:
    • Common antiepileptic drugs used:
      • Sodium valproate
      • Levetiracetam
      • Topiramate
    • Lifelong therapy is usually required due to a high chance of seizure recurrence.
    • Complete remission is rare, hence long-term follow-up is essential.

Explanation of other options:

Atypical absence seizures (Option B): More common in younger children and associated with developmental delays and slow spike-wave patterns on EEG (1-2 Hz), not myoclonic jerks.

Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (Option C): This epilepsy syndrome presents in younger children with multiple seizure types (tonic, atonic, atypical absence) and developmental delay, not myoclonic jerks triggered by awakening or stress.

Centrotemporal spikes (Option D): Typically occurs in children between 3-13 years, often during sleep, with focal facial seizures, not generalized myoclonic jerks.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a sudden onset of high fever, rapid breathing, inspiratory stridor, difficulty swallowing, and drooling. These symptoms began within the past 4-6 hours. Which of the following treatments should be started in addition to airway stabilization?
questions.solution:
The child presents with acute onset of high fever, stridor, dysphagia, and drooling, which is classic for acute epiglottitis. After ensuring airway security, the next crucial step is initiating intravenous antibiotics such as ceftriaxone or cefotaxime to treat the underlying infection.

Acute Epiglottitis:

  • A severe, rapidly progressive infection of the epiglottis and nearby tissues.
  • Can result in airway obstruction, hypoxia, and respiratory failure if not promptly managed.
  • Common Pathogens
    • Pre-vaccine era: Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) was the primary cause.
    • Post-Hib vaccine era: Other bacteria have become more common:
      • Streptococcus pneumoniae (most frequent now)
      • Streptococcus pyogenes
      • Non-typeable Haemophilus influenzae
      • Staphylococcus aureus
    • Widespread use of Hib vaccine has led to a >99% drop in Hib-related cases.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Sudden onset with high-grade fever and toxic appearance.
    • Drooling due to inability to swallow saliva.
    • Inspiratory stridor (a late and dangerous sign of airway narrowing).
    • Tripod posture: Sitting forward with neck extended to ease breathing.
    • Rapid breathing, anxiety, and possible cyanosis.
    • If untreated, may progress to loss of consciousness or respiratory arrest.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Laryngoscopy: Shows swollen, cherry-red epiglottis.
    • Lateral neck X-ray: Classic "thumb sign" (enlarged epiglottis).
    • Blood and throat cultures: Collected after securing the airway.
    • CSF analysis: May be done if meningeal signs are present.
  • Treatment
    • Airway management is the top priority:
      • Early intubation or tracheostomy in case of severe obstruction.
    • Empiric IV antibiotics for 7-10 days:
      • Choices: Ceftriaxone, cefepime, or meropenem.
    • Supportive care: Oxygen, IV fluids, and close monitoring in ICU.
  • Prognosis:
    • With prompt treatment, most children recover within a few days.
    • Mortality drops significantly (<1%) with airway protection and antibiotics.

Explanation of other options:

Nebulisation with racemic adrenaline (Option A): Racemic adrenaline is primarily used in croup (laryngotracheobronchitis), not epiglottitis. It provides temporary airway relief in subglottic obstruction, whereas epiglottitis involves supraglottic swelling.

Diphtheria antitoxin (Option C): Diphtheria antitoxin is used to neutralize the toxin in diphtheria, which presents with grayish pseudomembranes in the throat, not a swollen epiglottis with drooling and tripod posture.

Start steroids (Option D): Steroids are used in croup to reduce subglottic inflammation but are not indicated in epiglottitis, which involves supraglottic swelling and requires antibiotics after airway stabilization.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441873/
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK431070/
  3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430960/
  4. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1930043321002156

questions.text:
A 2-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a sudden onset of choking while playing. On examination, breath sounds are diminished over the left lung field. What are the most appropriate steps in the initial management of this child?
1. Bronchoscopy
2. Computed tomography scan
3. ICD insertion
4. Chest x-ray
questions.solution:
The child’s sudden choking episode with reduced breath sounds on one side suggests foreign body aspiration causing lower airway obstruction. The initial management includes a chest X-ray as the first-line investigation to detect signs like unilateral hyperinflation or collapse. If suspicion persists, bronchoscopy is the definitive diagnostic and therapeutic procedure for confirmation and removal of the foreign body.

Lower Airway Foreign Body Aspiration:

  • Epidemiology:
    • A common emergency in young children, especially those under 4 years of age.
    • Most cases occur in toddlers and older infants during play or eating.
  • Frequent Aspirated Items:
    • Food-related: Nuts, seeds, hard candy, chewing gum, bones, pieces of fruits or vegetables.
    • Non-food items: Coins, balloons, small toys, magnets, pen caps, pins, and jewelry.
  • Typical Sites of Lodgement:
    • Most commonly affects the bronchi, followed by the trachea, and then the larynx.
  • Types of Obstruction:
    • Partial Obstruction:
      • Acts as a one-way valve during expiration, leading to localized air trapping or hyperinflation.
      • Clinical signs: Reduced breath sounds, hyperresonance, and diminished vocal fremitus on the affected side.
    • Complete Obstruction:
      • Causes lung collapse (atelectasis) and can eventually result in chronic lung damage like bronchiectasis.
  • Clinical Phases:
    • Initial Phase: Sudden coughing, choking, or gagging during the aspiration event.
    • Asymptomatic Phase: Temporary relief may follow, which can delay diagnosis if the foreign body remains lodged.
    • Complications Phase: Later symptoms may include fever, persistent cough, hemoptysis, pneumonia, or localized lung collapse.
  • Diagnostic Approach:
    • History: A witnessed choking episode is often the most critical clue.
    • Chest X-ray (Option 4): First-line investigation; although many foreign bodies are radiolucent, secondary signs like unilateral hyperinflation or collapse may be seen.
    • Expiratory Films: Helpful in showing air trapping in suspected cases.
    • CT Chest (Option 2): Offers detailed imaging but involves radiation exposure; considered when X-rays are inconclusive.
    • Bronchoscopy (Option 1): Definitive diagnostic and therapeutic tool, especially if suspicion remains despite negative imaging.
  • Management:
    • Rigid Bronchoscopy: Gold standard for both diagnosis and removal of the foreign object.
    • Antibiotic Therapy: May be required if secondary infection is suspected.

Explanation of other options:

ICD insertion (Option 3): Intercostal Drain (ICD) is used for pleural pathologies like pneumothorax, not for airway obstructions.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is evaluated for short stature. Clinical assessment reveals a disproportionately long lower segment compared to the upper segment, with an upper segment to lower segment (US/LS) ratio of 0.8:1. Which of the following conditions best explains this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia is an inheritable skeletal dysplasia that primarily affects the spine and epiphyses of long bones. It leads to short trunk dwarfism, which means the upper segment is shorter than the lower segment, resulting in a low US/LS ratio.

  • Upper Segment: From the vertex to the pubic symphysis
  • Lower Segment: From the pubic symphysis to the floor
  • US/LS Ratio:
    • At birth: ~1.7
    • By 7 years: ~1.0
    • In adults: ~0.9

Explanation of other options:

Growth hormone deficiency (Option C): Results in proportionate short stature with normal US/LS ratio (approximately 0.9 in adults), unlike the disproportionate long lower segment seen in this case.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child weighing 10 kg is brought to a rural eye screening camp. On examination, the child is found to have a softened and thinned cornea, suggestive of keratomalacia. What is the appropriate therapeutic dose of vitamin A for this child?
questions.solution:
Keratomalacia indicates severe vitamin A deficiency. For children over 12 months, the therapeutic dose is 200,000 IU orally on Day 1, repeated on Day 2, and again after 4 weeks, per WHO guidelines.


Reference:

  1. The eye signs of vitamin A deficiency - PMC
  2. WHO Treatment for Vit A Deficiency
  3. RETINOL = VITAMIN A oral | MSF Medical Guidelines
